scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-206 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-206 is a star with 1.05 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.19 times its radius. It is located 1938.82 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-206 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-206 system


Kepler-206 b

Kepler-206 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-206 b is 1.870 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-206 b is 1.200 that of Earth. At 1.870 Earth masses, Kepler-206 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-206 c

Kepler-206 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-206 c is 3.784 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-206 c is 1.770 that of Earth. At 3.784 Earth masses, Kepler-206 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-206 d

Kepler-206 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-206 d is 1.813 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-206 d is 1.190 that of Earth. At 1.813 Earth masses, Kepler-206 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-206, which contains 3 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-206 - System With 3 Exolanets
